guideline: Adults aged 18–64 should perform at least 150–300 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic physical activity per week, or at least 75–150 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity.
source: World Health Organization (WHO) Global recommendations on Physical Activity for Health, 2020

guideline: A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins, while limiting saturated fats, trans fats, sodium, and added sugars, is associated with reduced risk of cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and certain cancers.
source: Dietary Guidelines for Americans 2020–2025, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

guideline: Adults should aim for 7–9 hours of quality sleep per night. Chronic sleep deprivation is linked to increased risk of obesity, type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and mental health disorders.
source: National Sleep Foundation Sleep Duration Recommendations, 2015; CDC Sleep and Health, 2022

guideline: Smoking cessation at any age is beneficial. Within 1 year of quitting, excess coronary heart disease risk is reduced by half. Within 15 years, cardiovascular risk approaches that of a non-smoker.
source: U.S. Surgeon General's Report on Smoking Cessation, 2020

guideline: Regular blood pressure monitoring is recommended for all adults. Hypertension (≥130/80 mmHg by AHA standards) significantly increases risk of stroke and heart disease. Lifestyle modifications include reducing sodium intake, increasing physical activity, and maintaining a healthy weight.
source: American Heart Association (AHA) Hypertension Guidelines, 2017

guideline: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening for colorectal cancer starting at age 45 for average-risk adults, using stool-based tests, flexible sigmoidoscopy, or colonoscopy.
source: USPSTF Colorectal Cancer Screening Recommendation, 2021

guideline: Mental health and physical health are deeply interconnected. Chronic stress elevates cortisol levels and is associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease, immune dysfunction, and mental health disorders. Evidence-based stress management strategies include mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and regular physical exercise.
source: American Psychological Association (APA) Stress and Health, 2023; NIH MBSR Research

guideline: Excessive alcohol consumption increases risk of liver disease, certain cancers, and cardiovascular disease. The USPSTF recommends screening for unhealthy alcohol use in primary care. Low-risk drinking is defined as ≤1 drink/day for women and ≤2 drinks/day for men.
source: USPSTF Alcohol Misuse Screening and Counseling, 2018; NIAAA Guidelines

guideline: Maintaining a healthy body weight (BMI 18.5–24.9) and waist circumference (men <40 inches, women <35 inches) reduces risk of type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, sleep apnea, and certain cancers. Weight management is best achieved through a combination of diet, exercise, and behavioral support.
source: NIH Clinical Guidelines on the Identification, Evaluation, and Treatment of Overweight and Obesity in Adults, 1998 (updated 2023)

guideline: Adequate hydration (approximately 3.7 liters/day for men, 2.7 liters/day for women from all beverages and foods) supports kidney function, cognitive performance, and thermoregulation. These values vary based on activity level, climate, and health status.
source: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM) Dietary Reference Intakes for Water, 2004

guideline: Preventive vaccinations across the lifespan significantly reduce morbidity and mortality. Adults should follow the CDC immunization schedule, including annual influenza vaccines, COVID-19 boosters, and Tdap, shingles (Shingrix), and pneumococcal vaccines at appropriate ages.
source: CDC Adult Immunization Schedule, 2024

guideline: Social connection and strong relationships are associated with lower mortality risk. Loneliness and social isolation are linked to a 29% increased risk of heart disease and 32% increased risk of stroke. Community engagement and maintaining close relationships are evidence-based preventive health behaviors.
source: U.S. Surgeon General's Advisory on the Healing Effects of Social Connection, 2023

guideline: Seasonal influenza prevention includes annual flu vaccination, frequent handwashing, and staying home when sick. People at higher risk (e.g., older adults, young children, pregnancy, and chronic conditions) should seek medical advice early if they develop severe symptoms such as difficulty breathing or chest pain.
source: CDC Influenza (Flu) Prevention and Risk Groups, 2023

guideline: Antibiotics treat bacterial infections and do not work against viruses (such as common colds and most sore throats). Unnecessary antibiotic use contributes to antibiotic resistance. Seek medical evaluation for persistent fever, difficulty breathing, or worsening symptoms.
source: CDC Antibiotic Use and Resistance Basics, 2022

guideline: Migraine management commonly includes identifying triggers, maintaining regular sleep, hydration, and discussing appropriate treatment options with a clinician. Seek urgent medical care for sudden, severe headache ('worst headache'), neurologic symptoms, or new headache with fever.
source: NIH/NINDS Migraine Overview (patient education), 2021

guideline: Asthma management should be guided by a clinician using symptom patterns and lung function. Seek urgent care for severe shortness of breath, trouble speaking in full sentences, or symptoms not responding to a rescue inhaler.
source: Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) Patient Guidance (summary), 2023

guideline: Type 2 diabetes risk increases with excess weight, family history, physical inactivity, and age. Screening is recommended for adults with risk factors. Lifestyle approaches that support lower risk include regular physical activity and healthier eating patterns, alongside clinician guidance when indicated.
source: American Diabetes Association Standards of Care (patient summary), 2024

guideline: Panic attacks can cause intense fear and physical symptoms (e.g., racing heart, shortness of breath). Evidence-based approaches include cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and breathing-based coping strategies. Seek urgent medical evaluation if symptoms could reflect a medical emergency or are new/severe.
source: NIMH Panic Disorder (patient education), 2022

guideline: Sun protection behaviors reduce risk of skin cancer and sunburn. Recommendations include using broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 30+), seeking shade, and wearing protective clothing. Reapply sunscreen at least every 2 hours and after swimming or sweating.
source: American Academy of Dermatology (AAD) Sun Protection Guidance, 2023

guideline: Warning signs that require urgent evaluation include chest pain, severe difficulty breathing, fainting, or sudden neurologic deficits (weakness, facial droop, slurred speech). Do not delay emergency care if these occur.
source: AHA/CDC Emergency Warning Signs (patient summary), 2022

guideline: Iron deficiency can cause fatigue, weakness, and pale skin. Diagnosis requires blood testing (e.g., hemoglobin and ferritin). Treatment depends on the cause and should be guided by a clinician.
source: NIH Office of Dietary Supplements — Iron (patient summary), 2021

guideline: Sleep hygiene strategies can support better sleep, including consistent sleep schedules, reducing evening screen exposure, and creating a comfortable sleep environment. If insomnia persists, evaluation by a healthcare professional may be needed.
source: American Academy of Sleep Medicine — Behavioral Sleep Advice (patient summary), 2021
